comments:
LGST 101 presents law as an evolving social institution, with special emphasis on the legal regulation of business. It
considers basic concepts of law and legal process, in the U.S. and other legal systems, and introduces the fundamentals of rigorous legal analysis. An in-depth examination of contract law is included.

Students noticed that Professor Nichols demanded in-depth thinking, and that they were required to go above and beyond the facts of the material. One student reported that there was a “Heavy emphasis on how to think - applying rules to facts to yield results.” This course is full of practical, lifelong information and models for thinking.

Several students commented that Professor Nichols was intimidating at first because of his cold calling, but nearly all students seemed to appreciate it more and more as the semester progressed because it “forced students to learn.” A few students did not enjoy this approach to teaching and thought it was “rude, disrespectful,” but this was a minority opinion.

Overall, this class comes with high recommendation to non-majors because of its practical application and the amount of thought-provoking material presented throughout the semester.

LGST 101 presents law as an evolving social institution, with special emphasis on the legal regulation of business. It considers basic concepts of law and legal process, in the U.S. and other legal systems, and introduces the fundamentals of rigorous legal analysis. An in-depth examination of contract law is included.

Students found that a great deal of practical knowledge was conveyed by Professor Miller. At times, his lectures were somewhat disconnected from the readings which some students found “superfluous,” but overall, students gained information they thought would be useful for their daily lives in the future.

Students really enjoyed Professor Miller’s engagement in class, his open lines of communication and his pragmatism. Many found him to be “interesting and an amazing lecturer.” Some criticism came with regards to the grading of tests and quizzes, but ultimately students seemed to highly recommend Professor Miller.

Overall, this class comes with high recommendation to non-majors because Professor Miller was great at stimulating interest and made the material easy to understand.

LGST 101 presents law as an evolving social institution, with special emphasis on the legal regulation of business. It considers basic concepts of law and legal process, in the U.S. and other legal systems, and introduces the fundamentals of rigorous legal analysis. An in-depth examination of contract law is included.

Students found that a great deal of practical knowledge was conveyed by Professor Miller. At times, his lectures were somewhat disconnected from the readings which some students found “superfluous,” but overall, students gained information they thought would be useful for their daily lives in the future.

Students really enjoyed Professor Miller’s engagement in class, his open lines of communication and his pragmatism. Many found him to be “interesting and an amazing lecturer.” Some criticism came with regards to the grading of tests and quizzes, but ultimately students seemed to highly recommend Professor Miller.

Overall, this class comes with high recommendation to non-majors because Professor Miller was great at stimulating interest and made the material easy to understand.

LGST 101 presents law as an evolving social institution, with special emphasis on the legal regulation of business. It considers basic concepts of law and legal process, in the U.S. and other legal systems, and introduces the fundamentals of rigorous legal analysis. An in-depth examination of contract law is included.

Students frequently wrote that many simple topics were unnecessarily examined at length. Professor Bauer taught in a unique style and took the class on interesting tangents but didn’t necessarily follow a plan as other professors tend to follow.

Professor Bauer’s teaching style seems to appeal to a particular type of student. Students felt he was an expert in the subject and was thought provoking, forcing students to engage in the material. Others, though, felt him very hard to follow and thought he made very simple topics difficult. One person described him as “haphazard” in his presentation of material.

Overall, this class may come with less recommendation for non-majors as some of the material presented can dive very deep into certain areas. The class is not taught as a survey course.
